Black History Month is a time to celebrate the courage, creativity and resilience of Black Americans and pay special attention to the extraordinary political, scientific, artistic and cultural contributions made by Black Americans even under the most trying circumstances.
Today, Black women still account for less than 3% of U.S. doctors. We still have more to do. But 150 years ago Dr. Rebecca Lee Crumpler blazed a trail to follow.
She was buried in an unmarked grave. But today, she is rightly recognized as one of the mothers of American medicine.

Dr. Crumpler treated women and children regardless of their ability to pay, and published the groundbreaking "A Book of Medical Discourses," on women‚Äôs health. https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/16/obituaries/rebecca-lee-crumpler-overlooked.html

She moved to Virginia and found ‚Äúthe proper field for real missionary work," caring for "the least of these" by helping the Freedman‚Äôs Bureau assist over four million formerly-enslaved Americans make the transition to a free life.

Rebecca entered medical school around the outbreak of the civil war, and graduated to become the only Black woman out of America's 54,543 known doctors. It's likely that during her life she never knew that she was America's first Black female doctor. https://www.pbs.org/newshour/health/celebrating-rebecca-lee-crumpler-first-african-american-physician.

Dr. Rebecca Lee Crumpler was the first Black woman in America to earn a degree as a medical doctor. Hospitals and pharmacies shunned her, but she persevered, bringing critical medical knowledge to poor communities. Here's her story. #BlackHistoryMonth http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FKhG4RSWQAMRlEm.jpg

I have some suggestions...

I encourage the next generation of civic leaders to pick up where my generation leaves off. Advocate. Organize. Run for office! And keep the faith. (15/16)

Today, Jim Crow lives on through Republican efforts to suppress voting. If their war on democracy reaches its logical conclusion, we stand to lose decades of progress toward racial justice. (12/16)

In the meantime, I‚Äôm fighting alongside my fellow Black Members of Congress to pass legislation that takes the needs of the Black community seriously. (9/16)

To be Black ‚Äî and specifically, a Black woman ‚Äî in America is to be underappreciated, underestimated and underrepresented.

More than 12% of our country‚Äôs population is Black. 

Yet our nation‚Äôs history, we have had only two Black #SCOTUS Justices, both of whom were men.

The Supreme Court‚Äôs decisions affect EVERY American. Diverse perspectives on that bench are a must. (5/16)

America prides itself on being a representative democracy. However, a representative government must truly *represent* the people it serves. 

As it stands now, this is not the case. (4/16)

Our nation is still governed overwhelmingly by the white, the male and the wealthy. Our leaders in the federal government make decisions for the entire country, including those whose lived experiences are nothing like their own. (3/16)
